key_descriptions.id: Integer identifier after a rough popularity-based sort (lower id - more commonly discussed/used).
key_descriptions.slug: Stable snake_case identifier for code/DB keys.
key_descriptions.name: Human-readable strategy name.
key_descriptions.date: Earliest known publication/appearance date for the strategy (year or YYYY-MM-DD).
key_descriptions.description: One-paragraph overview of what the count emphasizes and how it is typically used.
key_descriptions.games: Which blackjack table formats the strategy is commonly used for (e.g., pitch=hand-dealt, shoe=multi-deck).
key_descriptions.min_decks: Recommended minimum number of decks (integer) based on typical usage/author guidance.
key_descriptions.balance: true if the tag values sum to ~0 over a full 52-card deck; false if unbalanced.
key_descriptions.ace_neutral: true if the Ace has weight 0 in the main count (often implying reduced betting accuracy unless side-counted); false otherwise.
key_descriptions.weights: Array of tag values aligned with card_rank_order.
key_descriptions.metrics: Effectiveness metrics. When available from QFIT: betting_correlation (BC), playing_efficiency (PE), insurance_correlation (IC), and ease_of_use (1=hardest, 10=easiest).
key_descriptions.refs: References as structured citations; web refs include a URL and an accessed date.
key_descriptions.unique_fields: Optional flat (non-nested) fields capturing strategy-specific quirks.

strategies.name: Hi-Lo
strategies.description: A widely used level-1 balanced count that tracks low cards (2-6) as +1 and high cards (10-A) as -1 to estimate shoe richness; typically used with true-count conversion for betting and index play.

refs.citation: N. Wattenberger, "Hi-Lo - Card Counting Strategy," QFIT.com.
M. Shackleford, "Introduction to the High-Low Card Counting Strategy," Wizard of Odds.
S. Wong, Professional Blackjack. Pi Yee Press, 1975 (rev. ed. 1994).
E. O. Thorp, Beat the Dealer. Random House, 1962 (rev. ed. 1966).

strategies.name: KO (Knock-Out) Count
strategies.description: A level-1 unbalanced count designed to avoid true-count conversion for betting by using fixed running-count thresholds ('pivots'); popular for shoe games due to simplicity.

refs.citation: N. Wattenberger, "K-O - Card Counting Strategy," QFIT.com.
O. Vancura and K. Fuchs, Knock-Out Blackjack. 1996.

strategies.name: Zen Count
strategies.description: A multi-level balanced count (tags up to ±2) that improves playing efficiency compared with level-1 counts; often used with true-count conversion and index play in both pitch and shoe games.

refs.citation: N. Wattenberger, "Zen Count - Card Counting Strategy," QFIT.com.
A. Snyder, Blackbelt in Blackjack. RGE Publishing, 1983.

strategies.name: Omega II Count
strategies.description: A powerful multi-level balanced count (typically paired with indexes and often an ace side count) designed to perform well in multi-deck shoes; strong playing efficiency but higher complexity than level-1 systems.

refs.citation: N. Wattenberger, "Omega II - Card Counting Strategy," QFIT.com.
B. Carlson, Blackjack for Blood. 1992.

unique_fields.note: Main count is ace-neutral; many practitioners add an ace side count to improve betting accuracy.

strategies.name: Hi-Opt I Count
strategies.description: A level-1 balanced ace-neutral count derived from earlier work by Charles Einstein; improves playing efficiency vs Hi-Lo but has weaker betting correlation unless supplemented (e.g., with an ace side count).

refs.citation: N. Wattenberger, "Hi-Opt I - Card Counting Strategy," QFIT.com.
L. Humble and C. Cooper, The World's Greatest Blackjack Book. 1980.

strategies.name: Hi-Opt II Count
strategies.description: A level-2 balanced ace-neutral count (tags up to ±2) generally considered very strong for single-deck play; often paired with an ace side count when used in shoes to improve betting accuracy.

refs.citation: N. Wattenberger, "Hi-Opt II - Card Counting Strategy," QFIT.com.
UNLV Libraries, "Hi-opt II system for winning at casino blackjack" (catalog record).

unique_fields.note: Commonly cited as originating from a proprietary 'Hi-Opt II Report' before appearing in later blackjack literature.

strategies.name: Revere Point Count (RPC)
strategies.description: A strong balanced multi-level count (often considered a 'sweet spot' between Hi-Lo and more complex counts) with excellent betting correlation; frequently recommended for shoe games.

refs.citation: N. Wattenberger, "Revere Point Count - Card Counting Strategy," QFIT.com.
L. Revere, Playing Blackjack as a Business. 1980.

strategies.name: Revere Plus-Minus (Advanced Plus-Minus)
strategies.description: A level-1 balanced ace-neutral count used historically as a stepping stone toward more complex Revere systems; similar in spirit to Hi-Lo but shifts the Ace to neutral.

refs.citation: N. Wattenberger, "Revere Plus-Minus - Card Counting Strategy," QFIT.com.
L. Revere, Playing Blackjack as a Business. 1980.

unique_fields.note: Ace-neutral main count; betting accuracy is typically improved with additional information (e.g., ace tracking/side counting).

strategies.name: Ace/Five Count
strategies.description: An extremely simple count that tracks only Aces (-1) and Fives (+1). It is often used for low-profile play and comp-hunting, typically without index deviations and usually with a fixed spread in shoe games.

refs.citation: M. Shackleford, "The Ace/Five Count," Wizard of Odds.
E. O. Thorp, Beat the Dealer. (Similar 'five count' idea discussed in later printings, as noted by Wizard of Odds.)
L. Revere, Playing Blackjack as a Business. (Revere Five Count Strategy; cited by Wizard of Odds as 1971 edition).
Blackjack Review, "Card Counting System Comparisons" (Ace-Five metrics row).

unique_fields.betting_rule_of_thumb: Double last bet when running count >= 2 (Wizard of Odds presentation)
unique_fields.note: Designed to be most effective in deep-penetration shoe games; commonly played with basic strategy only.

strategies.name: Mentor Count
strategies.description: A balanced level-2 count with good all-around correlations; typically used with true-count conversion and a moderate index set. Often cited as a practical alternative to more complex level-3 systems.

refs.citation: N. Wattenberger, "Mentor - Card Counting Strategy," QFIT.com.
F. Renzey, Blackjack Bluebook II. 2003.

strategies.name: Uston APC (Advanced Point Count)
strategies.description: A high-power balanced level-3 count aimed at strong playing efficiency (many indexes); more demanding mentally but historically popular among advanced players for shoe games.

refs.citation: N. Wattenberger, "Uston APC - Card Counting Strategy," QFIT.com.
K. Uston, Million Dollar Blackjack. Gambling Times Inc., 1981.

strategies.name: Uston SS Count
strategies.description: A popular unbalanced count from Uston's later work; often paired with an initial running count and shoe-specific thresholds, trading some elegance for practical speed at the table.

refs.citation: N. Wattenberger, "Uston SS - Card Counting Strategy," QFIT.com.
K. Uston, Ken Uston on Blackjack. 1986.

strategies.name: UBZ 2 (Unbalanced Zen II / Unbalanced Zen 11)
strategies.description: An unbalanced variant inspired by Zen-style tags, optimized for betting with running-count thresholds; designed as a simpler approach than full true-count systems while retaining good overall strength.

refs.citation: N. Wattenberger, "UBZ 2 - Card Counting Strategy," QFIT.com.
N. Wattenberger, "Blackjack Strategies Summary" (Unbalanced Zen published 1995), QFIT.com.

strategies.name: Silver Fox Count
strategies.description: A level-1 balanced count optimized for betting and similar to the Green Fountain family; popular for its simplicity and shoe-game friendliness while remaining balanced (true-count capable).

refs.citation: N. Wattenberger, "Silver Fox - Card Counting Strategy," QFIT.com.
Blackjack Review, "Card Counting System Comparisons" (Silver Fox row).
R. Stricker, The Silver Fox Blackjack System. Silver Fox Enterprises, 1981 (revised ed. 1996).

unique_fields.note: Often described as closely related to (or virtually identical in tags to) Green Fountain counts.

strategies.name: Ten Count (Thorp)
strategies.description: An early 'ten-richness' approach that heavily contrasts ten-value cards against all non-tens; historically important but rarely used today compared with modern point-count systems.

refs.citation: E. O. Thorp, Beat the Dealer. Random House, 1962 (rev. ed. 1966).

unique_fields.note: Often implemented as a ratio/ten-density idea; this tag version is a balanced encoding with 16 tens versus 36 non-tens.

strategies.name: Revere 14 Count
strategies.description: A high-power balanced multi-level count (large tag magnitudes) with strong correlations, historically presented for serious single-deck play; very demanding mentally.

refs.citation: N. Wattenberger, "Revere 14 Count - Card Counting Strategy," QFIT.com.
L. Revere, The Complete Book of Blackjack. 1974.

strategies.name: Canfield Expert Count
strategies.description: A balanced level-1-style count tuned for single-deck play, with neutral Ace and 2 but positive 3-7; often cited as a practical step up in playing efficiency without going multi-level.

refs.citation: N. Wattenberger, "Canfield Expert - Card Counting Strategy," QFIT.com.
R. A. Canfield, Canfield Expert System. 1977.

strategies.name: BRH-0 Count
strategies.description: A shoe-oriented unbalanced count from the BRH family; designed to be strong for betting while remaining practical for real-time play.

refs.citation: Blackjack Review, "Card Counting System Comparisons" (BRH rows).
Blackjack Review, "BRH Systems."

strategies.name: BRH-I Count
strategies.description: A more aggressive unbalanced BRH variant with excellent betting correlation; typically presented as a shoe-game count with running-count thresholds.

refs.citation: Blackjack Review, "Card Counting System Comparisons" (BRH rows).
Blackjack Review, "BRH Systems."

strategies.name: BRH-II Count
strategies.description: A higher-level unbalanced BRH variant that shifts weight toward mid cards; typically used with shoe-game thresholds and can resemble some level-2 balanced counts in structure.

refs.citation: Blackjack Review, "Card Counting System Comparisons" (BRH rows).
Blackjack Review, "BRH Systems."
